repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Agricultural
            Privatization and Smallholder Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is unsatisfactory,
            sustainability unlikely, and the institutional development
            impact negligible, in addition to unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank, and Borrower. Among the key
            lessons, it is once again specified that structural reforms
            not only require the analytical capacity to propose, and
            accept changes, but also the capacity to implement them,
            thus implementation plans need to be developed in relation
            to the capacity of the agencies undertaking reforms,
            therefore, project design should be simple to accommodate
            the borrowers limited, and weak institutional, and
            administrative capacity. Moreover, project implementation
            involving land tenure reform, require not only strong
            political commitment, but clear operational, and sustainable
            institutional capacity design, which should be tested prior
            to large scale implementation. Additionally, the excessive
            salary disparities between project staff, and those from
            other agencies involved in the same development process as
            the project, leads to inadequate responsiveness, and
            non-compliance with targets, or project objectives. And, if
            co-financing is not assured in the timeframe required, the
            project should be redesigned, with additional funding
            available to finance needed activities until donor support
            is obtained. Finally, assessment of the regulatory framework
            should be reviewed up-front at project preparation,
            particularly as in this case, since the decree implementing
            land nationalization should have been passed as a loan conditionality.

repnme.cdata!:
Sao Tome and Principe - Agricultural
            Privatization and Smallholder Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will increase and diversify
            agricultural production through privatizing the
            publicly-owned agricultural estate sector and promoting
            smallholder production.  Privatization will increase
            production efficiency, eliminate the financial losses of the
            estate sector and provide incentives to diversify production
            into food and other crops. Secondary objectives of the
            project are rural poverty alleviation, diversified and
            sustainable growth in agriculture, and environmental
            protection. The rights of women to obtain land and access to
            agricultural support services are guaranteed under the land
            distribution criteria and procedures.  The project includes
            the following components: (a) land distribution; (b) labor
            reduction and economic support measures; (c) operational and
            management reform of the cocoa sector; and (d) agricultural
            sector administration and support services.
